SENT.plain: Miller-Dieker syndrome (MDS) is a prototype of brain malformations characterized by abnormal neuronal migration

To clarify the pathomechanisms underlying these anomalies, we performed immunohistochemical studies using specific antibodies against the protein product of LIS-1, the candidate gene responsible for the MDS phenotype
The LIS-1 protein was present abundantly and ubiquitously in normally developing brains

Loss of LIS-1 immunoreactivity was observed in brains with MDS, but not in brains with other malformations, such as isolated lissencephaly, holoprosencephaly, Fukuyama-type congenital muscular dystrophy, and Zellweger syndrome
These results suggest that the pathomechanism underlying abnormal neuronal migration in MDS may be specific to this particular type of malformation
